flowRoot.flowPara: gear_profile.py can generates 3 types of gear part:
The primitive diameter is a reference circle. Two gearwheels should have their their primitive_diameter in contact in exactly one point.
The parameter --second_gear_additional_axe_length breaks this rule. It is mostly used for experimentation. In regular case, keep the parameter second_gear_additional_axe_length to zero.
Two gearwheels are compatible (work together) if:
if this condition is not respected, you get a collision at each tooth transition. The motion is irregular.

gear_hollow_height_pourcentage and gear_router_bit_radius are in concurrence to set the depth of the hollow. The gear_hollow_height_pourcentage is percentage of the tooth half-height and ensure that the tops of the other teeth do not bang the bottom. The gear_outer_bit_radius ensure the gear is makable with a 3-axis CNC. If the hollow must be done deeper because of the router_bit, you get a warning message.
C is the intersection of (DB) and (AE)
(ABD) = pi/2 because of the 'involute to a circle'
(EDB) = pi/2 because of the 'involute to a circle'
With the Thales theorem, we have:
Let's choose primitive_1, N1, N2, base_diameter_1 and additional_axe_length=0
Result 1: If additional_axe_length=0, C is the contact point between the two primitive circle
Result 2: If the base_diameter_1/primitive_1 is smaller, then the force_angle is bigger.

The maximal possible value for the base_diameter is the primitive diameter. In this extrem case, the thooth height is zero, the force_angle=0, the gear wheel works with adhesion which is not what we want.
Tangential force on the tooth profile are side effect and must be reduced by using a slippery surface. The active force transmission rely on the radial direction force over the tooth profile.
The base_diameter must be as big as possible to reduce the force angle but small enough to get an active tooth height.
Q1: What happens when the base diameter is bigger than the dedendum circle?
The top of a tooth use the bottom of the tooth of the other gearwheel.
if base_1>dedendum_1, then the top of the gearwheel_2 is not used and addendum_2 can be reduced. Not the full tooth_height is used. So, it is more optimum to keep base<dedendum.
Optimum, we choose base=dedendum for the smaller gearwheel. And then we get the base_dieamter of the bigger gearwheel.
If we want to increase the length of the 'tooth contact path' or if we want to increase the force_angle, then we increase the tooth_height.
